case_name: M/s J. Burman Co. v. Union of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 328 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 328 of 1961. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 2, 1961 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Revision Application No. 135-D of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 2, 1961, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench , at Delhi in Civil Revision Application No. 135-D of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 25, 1961 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. September 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The principal point which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates

facts.text: Union of India filed petition in Court of First Class Sub-Judge at Delhi against M/s J. Burman Co. through proprietor Jawahar Lal Burman under ss. 33 and 28 of Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Union of India, filed a petition in the Court of the First Class Sub-Judge at Delhi against the appellant M s J. Burman Co., through its proprietor Jawahar Lal Burman under ss. 33 and 28 of the Act.

facts.text: Contract entered into between parties on August 31, 1949 for supply of 170-1/2 Cwt. of coconut oil by appellant to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent alleged that a companycluded companytract had been entered into between the parties on August 31, 1949 for supply of 170-1/2 Cwt. of companyoanut oil by the appellant to the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent advertised in Indian Trade Journal for supply, appellant submitted tender No. SM-I/1104524 which was accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had advertised in the Indian Trade Journal for the said supply and the appellant had submitted its tender No. SM-I/1104524. This tender was accepted by the respondent which companycluded a companytract between the parties.

facts.text: Contract governed by general conditions of contract Form W.S.B. 133 including arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case was that the said companytract was governed by general companyditions of companytract Form W.S.B. 133., These companyditions included an arbitration agreement,

facts.text: Disputes arose, referred to two arbitrators appointed by parties.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose between the parties regarding the said companytract, and so in pursuance of the arbitration agreement they were referred to the two arbitrators appointed by the parties.

facts.text: Appellant objected to arbitrators' jurisdiction claiming no concluded contract.

anchor.surface_text: After ,the arbitration propeedings had gone. on for, a companysiderable time before the arbitrators the appellant objected to their jurisdiction to , deal. with the disputes on the- ground that there was number companycluded companytract between the parties.

facts.text: Trial judge found concluded contract, valid arbitration agreement, court jurisdiction, granted one month's extension to arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: He found that a companycluded companytract had been proved, between the parties as alleged by the respodent. that there was a valid arbitration agreement in the said companytract and that the Court had jurisdiction, to. try the petition.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision petition in Punjab High Court at Chandigarh, dismissed confirming trial court findings.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was challenged by the appellant by its revision petition preferred in. the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh. The High Court has companyfirmed the finding of the trial companyrt that there was a companycluded companytract

facts.text: Arbitrators heard matter at length, proceedings reached stage for award when appellant raised no contract plea.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrators heard the matter at length and the proceedings bad reached a stage when an award might have been pronounced. It was then that the appellant chose to obstruct the further progress

facts.text: Appellant pleaded no concluded contract and no jurisdiction under s.28.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded in defence that numberconcluded companytract had been made between the parties and that there was numberjurisdiction in the Court to grant extension under s 28.

facts.text: No specific point raised by appellant on lack of jurisdiction under s.33 or s.32 in pleadings.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, it may be pointed out at this stage that numberspecific point had been raised in the pleadings of the appellant that, the Court had numberjurisdiction to entertain the petition under s. 33 or. s. 32 of the Act.

facts.text: Acceptance letter dated August 31, 1949 stated offer accepted subject to depositing 10% security.

anchor.surface_text: In this letter written on August 31, 1949 the respondent stated as follows Dear Sirs, Ref -Your tender No. and date Nil. Your offer is hereby accepted for a quantity of 1704 Cwts.

facts.text: Tender subject to conditions in Form W.S.B. 133, security deposit condition subsequent per clause 4(a) and 4(b).

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon-ground that the tender thus submitted was subject to the companyditions of companytract governing the Department of Supply Contracts which were set out in the Government Publication Form W. S. B.

facts.text: Supreme Court held trial court had jurisdiction under ss.32,33 to entertain petition.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold, though for different reasons, that the High Court was right in companying to the companyclusion that the petition made by the respondent was companypetent under s. 32 of the Act and has been properly entertained by the trial Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court found there was concluded contract, acceptance absolute and unqualified.

anchor.surface_text: reading the letter as a whole we do number think that the Courts below have erred in Coming to the companyclusion that this letter amounts to an absolute and unqualified acceptance of the tender or offer made by the appellant.

facts.text: Parties nominated their arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the respondent numberinated their arbitrators.

facts.text: Appellant refused to apply under s.33, causing stalemate in arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: Even then he refused to apply under s. 33 and so a stalemate issued because the arbitrators were number entitled to proceed further with the arbitration proceedings in view of the point raised by the appellant.

facts.text: Delivery ex-godown at Calcutta by 30-9-49 or earlier.

anchor.surface_text: packed in number-returnable sound, strong 45 gallon drums, delivery ex-godown at Calcutta, by 30-9-49 or earlier if possible subject to your depositing 10 as security.

facts.text: Security money Rs. 15,230/- to be deposited immediately.

anchor.surface_text: The security money which companyes to Rs. 15,230/-  Rupees fifteen thousand two hundred and thirty only  should please be deposited immediately into a Government Treasury

facts.text: Contract concluded by this acceptance, formal acceptance to follow on receipt of Treasury Receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract is companycluded by this acceptance and formal acceptance of Tender will follow immediately on receipt of Treasury Receipt.

facts.text: Trial judge granted one month's time to arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently he granted a months time to the arbitrators to make their award.

issues.text: The principal point which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates to the construction of ss. 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, particularly whether the court has jurisdiction to entertain a petition affirming the existence and validity of an arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: The principal point which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates to the construction of ss. 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940  10 of 1940   hereafter called the Act . That question arises in this way.

issues.text: whether the trial court had jurisdiction to entertain the respondent's petition under ss. 33 and 28 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question of jurisdiction raised by the appellant has to be answered in the light of the construction which can be reasonably placed on the material provisions of ss. 32 and 33 of the Act. It may be conceded at the outset that the question thus raised presents some difficulty.

issues.text: what remedy it is open to a party to adopt in order to obtain an appropriate declaration about the existence or validity of an arbitration agreement when suit is barred by s. 32

anchor.surface_text: The bar to the suit thus created by s. 32 inevitably raises the question as to what remedy it is open to a party to adopt in order to obtain an appropriate declaration about the existence or validity of an arbitration agreement and it is on the decision of this question that the parties are at issue before us.

issues.text: whether a person affirming an arbitration agreement can apply under the latter part of s. 33 to have the effect of the arbitration agreement determined

anchor.surface_text: The question which we have to consider is whether a person affirming an arbitration agreement can apply under the latter part of s. Even assuming that the requirement that an application can be made under the first part of s. 33 only by persons desiring to challenge the arbitration agreement does not apply to its latter part,

issues.text: whether there was a concluded contract between the parties

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the next question as to whether there was a concluded contract between the parties or not. We have already noticed that in response to the advertisement published by the respondent in the Indian Trade Journal the appellant submitted its tender.

issues.text: whether the acceptance of the tender constituted an absolute and unqualified acceptance under s. 7 of the Contract Act or made the security deposit a condition precedent

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Din Dayal is right when he contends that s. 7 of the Contract Act requires that the acceptance of the offer must be absolute and unqualified, it cannot be conditional but reading the letter as a whole we do not think that the Courts below have erred in Coming to the conclusion that this letter amounts to an absolute and unqualified acceptance of the tender or offer made by the appellant.

arguments.claim: There was no concluded contract between the parties

arguments.court_reasoning: Tender acceptance letter constitutes absolute and unqualified acceptance under s.7 Contract Act; security deposit is condition subsequent per Form W.S.B. 133 cl.4.

arguments.claim: There is a lacuna in the Act: s.32 bars suits but no remedy by application provided

anchor.surface_text: Mr, Din Dayal contends that there is really a lacuna in the Act inasmuch as having created a bar by s. 32 the Legislature has failed to provide a remedy by way of an application.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s to the existence or validity in terms and ss. 31 and 32 also refer separately to the existence eff

arguments.court_reasoning: No lacuna on reading ss.31,32,33 together; s.32 implies application remedy.

arguments.claim: Party affirming arbitration agreement existence cannot apply under s.33

anchor.surface_text: In fairness we ought to add that the learned Solicitor-General, who appeared for the respondent, did not dispute this position.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; s.33 latter part for effect where existence not disputed.

arguments.claim: First part of s.33 only for parties challenging existence/validity of arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: Section 33 consists of two parts. The first deals with a challenge to the existence or validity of an arbitration agreement or an award, and it provides that the persons therein specified can apply to the Court

arguments.claim: Latter part of s.33 for determining effect of agreement only if existence not disputed; affirming party cannot use it for existence declaration

anchor.surface_text: The question which we have to consider is whether a person affirming an arbitration agreement can apply under the latter part of s. 33... Thus, under the latter part of s. 33 an application can be made to have the effect or purport of the agreement determined but not its existence.

arguments.claim: S.32 bar on suits implies remedy by application under court's inherent powers per s.31

anchor.surface_text: If s. 32 has created a bar against the institution of a suit... unless it is held that the creation of the said absolute bar itself involves the right to make an application under the Act... On this construction s. 33 cannot be treated as exhaustive

arguments.claim: Ss.32/33 enacted to prevent abuse of court process by dishonest denials of arbitration agreements post-proceedings

anchor.surface_text: In appreciating the effect of these two provisions it would be relevant to remember that the object of the Legislature in enacting the two sections quite clearly was to prevent the abuse of the process of the Court. Before the present Act was passed experience showed that unscrupulous

anchor.surface_text: We are inclined to think that the decision of the Bombay High Court is substantially correct.

arguments.claim: Security deposit per cl.4(a)(b) Form W.S.B.133 is condition subsequent, not precedent

anchor.surface_text: It is common-ground that the tender thus submitted was subject to the conditions of contract governing the Department of Supply Contracts which were set out in the Government Publication Form W. S. B. Clauses 4 a  and  b  of these conditions are relevant.

arguments.claim: Acceptance letter absolute and unqualified per s.7 Contract Act despite security mention; contract concluded

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Din Dayal is right when he contends that s. 7 of the Contract Act requires that the acceptance of the offer must be absolute and unqualified, it cannot be conditional but reading the letter as a whole we do not think that the Courts below

arguments.claim: Challenge to main contract same as to arbitration agreement where arb clause part of contract

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the substance of the matter the prayer was first in regard to the existence and the validity of the main contract leading upto the second and principal prayer that there was a valid arbitration agreement.

holdings.text: The court has inherent jurisdiction under s.32 read with s.31 of the Arbitration Act to entertain a petition by a party affirming the existence and validity of an arbitration agreement, as the bar on suits under s.32 implies a remedy by application.

anchor.surface_text: If s. 32 has created a bar against the institution of a suit... unless it is held that the creation of the said absolute bar itself involves the right to make an application under the Act... On this construction s. 33 cannot be treated as exhaustive of all cases where applications can be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of ss.31,32,33 avoids lacuna from s.32 suit bar without application remedy; aligns with ss.20,33 where affirming party can get declaration; prevents stalemate in arbitration.

holdings.text: A party affirming the existence of an arbitration agreement cannot apply under s.33 for a declaration of its existence.

anchor.surface_text: The question which we have to consider is whether a person affirming an arbitration agreement can apply under the latter part of s. 33... Thus, under the latter part of s. 33 an application can be made to have the effect or purport of the agreement determined but not its existence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading distinguishes existence/validity (first part s.33) from effect (latter part); affirming party use of latter part would make first part superfluous.

holdings.text: There is no lacuna in the Arbitration Act as ss.31,32,33 read together provide for applications affirming arbitration agreements via inherent jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: On reading ss. 31, 32 and 33 together we do not think the Court is driven to the conclusion that there is a lacuna in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's lacuna argument; s.32 bar implies application remedy, consistent with ss.20,33 outcomes.

holdings.text: The trial court had jurisdiction to entertain the petition under ss.32 and 33; High Court correct though for different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold, though for different reasons, that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the petition made by the respondent was competent under s. 32 of the Act and has been properly entertained by the trial Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower courts on jurisdiction via inherent power under s.32, not s.28 as High Court held.

holdings.text: Where arbitration agreement is part of main contract, a challenge to the main contract's existence/validity falls within s.32 bar and court's jurisdiction to declare on arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the substance of the matter the prayer was first in regard to the existence and the validity of the main contract leading upto the second and principal prayer that there was a valid arbitration agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form; challenge common to both means petition is for arbitration agreement declaration, barred as suit by s.32.

holdings.text: There was a concluded contract between the parties; the acceptance letter constitutes absolute and unqualified acceptance under s.7 Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the next question as to whether there was a concluded contract between the parties or not... reading the letter as a whole we do not think that the Courts below have erred in Coming to the conclusion that this letter amounts to an absolute and unqualified acceptance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter read wholly accepts offer per quantity, price, delivery; 'subject to depositing security' consistent with condition subsequent in Form W.S.B.133 cl.4; categorical 'contract concluded'.

holdings.text: Security deposit under Form W.S.B.133 cl.4(a),(b) is a condition subsequent, not precedent, to contract formation.

anchor.surface_text: It is common-ground that the tender thus submitted was subject to the conditions of contract... Clause 4 b makes it clear that the failure to make the deposit would be a breach of the contract itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard form terms: deposit at option post-acceptance; failure is breach, not non-formation.

holdings.text: s.28 does not confer power to decide existence/validity of arbitration agreement or entertain such petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Act has no material bearing on the decision of this point. The power to enlarge time for making the award... cannot be hold to include a power to entertain petitions like the present.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.28 limited to time extension; Solicitor-General concedes no such power.

holdings.text: Decision in Gulamali Abdulhussain (Bombay HC) substantially correct on inherent jurisdiction despite s.32.

anchor.surface_text: We are inclined to think that the decision of the Bombay High Court is substantially correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with inherent jurisdiction view over contrary precedents like Adamjee.

precedents.citation: Hayman v. Darwins, Ltd. 1  1942 A.C. 356. S. C. 1942 1 All. E. R. 337 at p. 347.

anchor.surface_text: As observed by Lord Macmillan in Hayman v. Darwins, Ltd. 1 , the arbitration clause is quite distinct from the other clauses. The other clauses set out the obligations which the parties undertake towards each other hinc inde but the arbitration clause does number impose on one of the parties an obligation in favour of the other. It embodies the agreement on both the parties that, if any dispute arises with regard to  1  1942 A.C. 356.

precedents.cited_proposition: Arbitration clause is distinct from other contract clauses as it does not impose obligations from one party to another but agrees to settle disputes by arbitration; it can be specifically enforced and may survive termination of the main contract or be independently void.
precedents.cited_holding: the arbitration clause does number impose on one of the parties an obligation in favour of the other. It embodies the agreement on both the parties that, if any dispute arises with regard to the obligations which the one party has undertaken to the other, such dispute shall be settled by a tribunal of their own companystitution.

precedents.citation: Messrs. Grulamali Abdulhussain Co. v. Messrs. Vishwambharlal Ruiya 1 1. L. R. 1950 Bom. 333.

anchor.surface_text: In Messrs. Grulamali Abdulhussain Co. v. Messrs. Vishwambharlal Ruiya 1  a petition had been filed for a declaration that the respondents had entered into the companytract with the petitioners for purchase of 500 bars of silver on or about January 30, 1948 according to the rules and regulations of the Marwari Chamber of Commerce, Ltd., and that the respondents were bound to have all disputes in companynection with the same companytract decided by the arbitrators as provided by the said rules and regulations. The companypetence of this petition and the jurisdiction of the Court to enter- tain it were disputed. Both the learned trial judge and the Court of Appeal rejected the respondents companytention and held that there was an inherent jurisdiction in the Court to entertain petitions in respect of matters companyered by the bar raised by 32.

precedents.case_name: Grulamali Abdulhussain & Co v Vishwambharlal Ruiya
precedents.cited_proposition: Court has inherent jurisdiction to entertain petitions seeking declaration of existence and validity of arbitration agreement where such suits are barred by section 32 of the Arbitration Act.

precedents.citation: Bajranglal Laduram v. Agarwal Brothers 2 A. I. R. 1950 Cal. 2.67.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, in Bajranglal Laduram v. Agarwal Brothers 2  as well as in State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood Co., a companytrary view has been accepted. In the latter case, a suit had been filed on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court claiming a declaration that a certain companytract was number made between the parties and was number binding on the plaintiff.

precedents.cited_proposition: Contrary view holding that courts do not have jurisdiction or that suits/petitions challenging arbitration agreements are not barred under sections 32 and 33.

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood Co., 3 1. L. R. 1952 2 Cal. 49.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, in Bajranglal Laduram v. Agarwal Brothers 2  as well as in State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood Co., a companytrary view has been accepted. In the latter case, a suit had been filed on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court claiming a declaration that a certain companytract was number made between the parties and was number binding on the plaintiff. A further claim was also made that it should be declared that the defendant was number entitled to make any claim in respect of the said companytract and that the companytract be adjudged void and delivered up as cancelled. The learned trial judge companystrued the plaint as one for declaration that the arbitration agreement companytained in the companytract was invalid and on that view he held that under ss. 32 and 33 of the Act the suit was number maintainable. On appeal it was held that the suit was number one for challenging the validity of the arbitration agreement merely it covered other reliefs and so bar of ss. 32 and 33 companyld number be pleaded.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v Adamjee Hajee Dawood & Co
precedents.cited_proposition: A suit challenging the main contract (declaring no contract exists, not binding, void) is not barred by ss.32 and 33 even if it incidentally involves the arbitration agreement, as it is not merely challenging the arbitration agreement.
precedents.cited_holding: the suit was number one for challenging the validity of the arbitration agreement merely it covered other reliefs and so bar of ss. 32 and 33 companyld number be pleaded.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold, though for different reasons, that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the petition made by the respondent was competent under s. 32 of the Act and has been properly entertained by the trial Court.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; upheld trial court and High Court findings on jurisdiction to entertain the petition under ss. 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act and existence of concluded contract containing valid arbitration agreement
